_meanings:
(Always <ab>pl.</ab>; <ab>nom.</ab>
and <ab>acc.</ab> {#paMca#}) Five. (As the first
member of <ab>comp.</ab> {#paMcan#} drops its final
{#n#}). [<ab>cf.</ab> <ab>Gr.</ab> {%pente%}]

{1} an
aggregate of five sacred fires; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} 

({#anvAhAryapacana#} or {#dakziRa, gArhapatya#}, 
{#AhavanIya, saBya#}, and {#AvasaTya#})

{2} a 
householder who maintains the five sacred
fires; {#paMcAgnayo DftavratAH#} <ls>Māl. 1</ls>;  
<ls>Ms. 3. 185.</ls>

{3} five mystic fires 
supposed to exist in the body.

{4} one who
is acquainted with the doctrine of
these fires.

{2} a kind of horse
with five spots in different parts of
his body.

{1} collection or aggregate of five
parts.

{%<ab>f.</ab>%} the
propitiousness or favourable state of
five important points; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#tiTi, vAra#},
{#nakzatra, yoga#}, and {#karaRa#} (in astrology).

the five products of the
goat.

<ab>N.</ab> of a lake, said
to have been created by the sage
Māṇḍakarṇi; <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>R. 13. 38.</ls>

{1}
the aggregate of any five drugs.

five-membered (as a syllogism, the
five members being, {#pratijYA, hetu#}, 
{#udAharaRa, upanaya#} and {#nigamana#} <ab>q. q. v.</ab> v.).

a corpse; (so called 
because it is resolved into the five 
elements); <ab>cf.</ab> {#paMcatva#} below.
the five products of the sheep.

doing 
penance with five fires ({%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} with four
fires and the sun); <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>R. 13. 41.</ls>

{3} the
sign Leo of the zodiac.

({%<ab>m.</ab>%} <ab>pl.</ab>) five
Śāstras supposed to have 
proceeded from the five mouths of Śiva.

an aggregate of the five organs
(of sense or actions; see {#iMdriyaM#}).

epithets of the god of
love; (so called because he has five
arrows: their names are:  
--{#araviMdamaSokaM ca cUtaM ca navamallikA . nIlotpalaM ca#}
{#pacEte paMcabARasya sAyakAH#}; the five 
arrows are also thus named:  
--{#saMmohanonmAdanO ca SozaRastApanastaTA .#} 
{#staMBanaSceti kAmasya paMcabARAH prakIrtitAH ..#}).

<ab>pl.</ab> the five digestive fires 
supposed to be in the body.
prepared or offered in five cups.

branded in the ear with the
number ‘five’ (as cattle &c.); <ab>cf.</ab>
<ls>P. VI. 3. 115.</ls>

(in medicine)
the five kinds of treatment; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%}

{4} {#anuvAsana#} ‘administering an enema
which is oily’, and

({%<ab>m.</ab>%} <ab>pl.</ab>)
the five vestures or wrappers 
supposed to invest the soul; they are:

the earthly body  
 ({#sTUlaSarIra#}); {#prARamayakoza#} the vesture of the
vital airs; {#manomayakoza#} the sensorial
vesture; {#vijYAnamayakoza#} the 
cognitional vesture (these three form the
{#liMgaSarIra#}); and {#AnaMdamayakoza#} the last
vesture, that of beatitude.

the five products of the cow
taken collectively; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} milk, curds,
clarified butter or ghee, urine, and
cowdung ({#kzIraM daDi taTA cAjyaM mUtraM#} 
{#gomayameva ca#}).

the
five objects of sense ({#rUpa, rasa, gaMDa#},
{#sparSa#} and {#Sabda#}).

{2} the
materialistic system of philosophy,
the doctrines of the Cārvākas.

{2} <ab>N.</ab> of a demon who had
assumed the form of a conch-shell,
and was slain by Kṛṣṇa.

{5} the four primary
castes of the Hindus ({#brAhmaRa, kzatriya#},
{#vESya#} and {#SUdra#}) with the Niṣādas or
barbarians as the fifth (<ab>pl.</ab> in
these two senses); (for a full 
exposition see Śārīrabhāṣya on Br. 
<ls>Br. Sūt. I. 4. 11-13</ls>).

{1} an
epithet of Buddha as possessing
the five kinds of knowledge.

{2} a
man familiar with the doctrines of
the Pāśupatas.

{2} (in the Tantras) the five
essentials of the Tāntrikas, also
called {#paMcamakAra#} because they all
begin with {#ma#}; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#madya, mAMsa, matsya#},
{#mudrA#}, and {#mETuna#}.

<ab>N.</ab> of a 
wellknown collection in five books
containing moral stories and fables

an ascetic who
in summer practises penance sitting
in the middle of four fires with
the sun burning right over his
head; <ab>cf.</ab> {#havirBujAmeDavatAM caturRAM maDye#}
{#lalAwaMtapasaptasaptiH#} <ls>R. 13. 41</ls> and  
<ls>Ku. 5. 23</ls>; and <ls>Ms. 6. 23</ls> and <ls>Śi. 2. 51</ls>
also.

{2} increased by fifteen; as
in {#paMcadaSaM SataM#} ‘one hundred and
fifteen’.

the fifteenth day of a lunar 

fortnight.

‘the
country of five rivers,’ the modern
Panjab (the five rivers being {#Satadru#},
{#vipASA, irAvatI, caMdraBAgA#} and {#vitastA#},
or the modern names Sutlej, Beas,
Ravee, Chenab and Jhelum).

waving five things before an idol
and then falling prostrate before it;
(the five things being:-- a lamp,
lotus, cloth, mango and betel-leaf).

{2} the five strong cases, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} the
first five inflections.

<ab>pl.</ab> the
five {%parvans%} <ab>q. v.</ab>; they are {#caturdaSyazwamI#}
{#cEva amAvAsyA ca pUrRimA . parvARyetAni rAjeMdraM#}
{#ravisaMkrAMtireva ca ..#}.

consisting of
five feet, steps, or parts.

{2} a Śrāddha
in which offerings are made in five
vessels.

<ab>pl.</ab> the five fathers:
--{#janakaScopanetA ca yaSca kanyAM prayacCati .#} 
{#annadAtA BayatrAtA paMcEte pitaraH smftAH ..#}.

({%<ab>m.</ab>%} <ab>pl.</ab>) the five life-winds or vita
airs; {#prARa, apAna, vyAna, udAna#} and {#samAna#}.

a temple of a particular
size with four pinnacles and a
steeple.

a fine equal to the
fifth part of anything lost or stolen.

epithets of the
god of love; see {#paMcezu#}.

{2} consisting of five good
ingredients (as a sauce &c.).

{3}
having five auspicious marks (asa
horse) on the chest, back, face and
flanks.

the five elements; {#pfTvI#}, 
{#ap, tejas, vAyu#} and {#AkASa#}.

the five essentials of the left-hand
Tantra ritual of which the first
letter is {#ma#}; see {#paMcatattva#} (2).

({%<ab>m.</ab>%} <ab>pl.</ab>) the five daily
sacrifices enjoined to be performed
by a Brāhmaṇa; see {#mahAyajYa#}.

consisting of five Māṣas
(as a fine &c.).

an
arrow with five points; (for other
senses see {#paMcAnana#}.)

five 
gestures to be made in presenting 
offerings to an idol.

{2} the
five most admired episodes of the
Mahābhārata.

five kinds of
salt; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#kAcaka, sEMDava, sAmudra, biqa#} and
{#sOvarcala#}.

a gift ({#mahAdAna#}) of
as much land as can be cultivated
with five ploughs.

the five metals; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} gold,
silver, copper, tin, and lead.

the sacred or sacrificial thread worn
across the breast ({#yajYopavIta#}).

{1} the five fig-trees; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#aSvatTa#}, 
{#bilva, vawa, DAtrI#}, and {#aSoka#}.

{2} <ab>N.</ab> of a
part of the Daṇḍakā forest where
the Godāvarī rises and where Rāma
dwelt for a considerable time with
his beloved; it is two miles from
Nasik; <ls>U. 2. 28</ls>; <ls>R. 13. 34.</ls>

{2} the five
essential elements of the body.

{4}
the five daily sacrifices enjoined to
be performed by a Brāhmaṇa; <ab>cf.</ab>
{#mahAyajYa#}.

a collection of the barks of
five kinds of trees; namely {#nyagroDa#},
{#uduMbara, aSvatTa, plakza#} and {#vetasa#}.

a collection 

of twenty-five; as in {#vetAlapaMcaviMSatikA#}.

{%<ab>f.</ab>%} the five departments of a
government; <ls>Ms. 7. 157.</ls>

<ab>pl.</ab> five or six;  
{#saMtyanye'pi bfhaspatipraBftayaH saMBAvitAH paMcazAH#}
<ls>Bh. 2. 34.</ls>

the five kinds of aromatic 
vegetable substances; they are:  
--{#karpUrakakkolalavaMgapuzpaguvAkajAtIPalapaMcakena .#} 
{#samAMSaBAgena ca yojitena manoharaM paMcasugaMDakaM syAt ..#}.

the five things in a house
by which animal life may be 
accidentally destroyed; they are:  
--{#paMcasUnA gfhasTasya cullIpezaRyupaskaraH kaMqanI#} 
{#codakuMBaSca#} <ls>Ms. 3. 68.</ls>
